author: oaklandmatt
content:
I have a different angle you could try. I would focus almost all your energy on becoming a better, more truthful, richer lyricist. That's the only place you'll be original because there's only one you. Paradoxically, it's also the way you'll write songs that have a universal appeal because the more personal you get, the more the underlying universal emotions will resonate with people.

Trying to be analytical about melodies and structure and style when writing has never yielded good songs for me or literally anyone I know. All the best songwriters I've met write all their best songs lyrics first.

Also, when you have something to say, it's surprising how little you pay attention to the melody. The melodies and structural components seem to just come when your heart is already in the story.

The only other thing I'd say is learn A+ songs. Learn the lyrics completely and learn the story behind them as much as possible. Then learn to sing them the way the original version is sung. That will expand your vocabulary as a vocalist and reinforce great lyrics.

Lastly, technology is going to continue to increasingly replace stylistic innovation. Yeah AI blah blah blah, but already drum machines and synth presets and splice and DAWs. The last thing to be replaced will be you personally writing things from your experience. Songs about your deepest insecurities and songs about your pet gerbil both fall into this category. Explore all of it.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Some songwriting-related morning routine thoughts:

I've been starting my day with doing piano scales and vocal warm ups to a metronome and then singing/ learning a song and recording a voice note of it. (recently it's been Tom Petty Wildflowers at the piano). Then I look at my phone and start my day.

Hard to know for sure if it's causal, but my songwriting abilities have sped up. I'm quicker in sessions, both with topline and tracks. 

I think it's related to several aspects of the morning routine, and they all compound. 

*I'm playing music before I'm on my phone, so I'm outputting music before my brain starts reacting.

*doing scales w piano and voice opens up my vocabulary on both instruments and makes me much more comfortable to sing/play ideas when writing
*doing these to a metronome has improved my timing on all instruments (not just piano and vocal)
*learning a great song and singing it every morning has massively improved my lyrical writing/ improvisation (probably the hardest part of songwriting) by just reinforcing good *sounding* words.
*singing and recording the same song every morning for a few days or a week makes me really THINK about vocals and vocal production. How I'm singing the words, how to push certain vowels in a certain part of my voice, etc 

@Slow Hand  @Ross Fortune @Will Melones @OJ

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Yes exactly! I've found that the best songs are never calculated, they're always just felt as they're being created. They are magical/ incalculable moments. As soon as people start analyzing – "is this too generic?" "maybe we should have a part like **insert artist**" – the songs loses its magic.

But the paradox is that you can't  just sit around and wait for them to happen. You have to be in motion. So often times building habits and processes (which are calculated) is a great way to keep oneself in the motion of creating things. Piano scales, learning songs, writing a song a day, etc., are just some of the many ways to do this.

And the other aspect is also correct. These are skill building exercises that help the quick translation of creative ideas. It's the emotional and psychological side of workflow. Just like technical workflow – where you want the shortest time between idea an execution – same goes for writing. If you are constantly writing lyrics and singing melodies and playing instruments, when that emotional magical idea arrives, you can translate it more quickly into lyrics, melody, and music.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Just had thanksgiving dinner at Alan Burgman’s house and we talked a good amount about songwriting. If you’re not familiar with his work, he’s 98 years old and has written lyrics for everyone from Frank Sinatra to Aretha Franklin to Quincey Jones to half of the artists your grandma listened to. 

Anyways, some good takeaways from last night’s convo:

“Writers these days are more interested in immediate appeal than they are in a great song. They aren’t the same thing. A great song is only a great song if people will want to cover it in 30 years” 

He cares immensely that whatever is being said in a song is worth saying. Does the message have strong intrinsic value?  

He’s verrrry quick to say he doesn’t like a song.

He has a strong preference for melody being written before the lyrics, which is particularly interesting consider his career is as a lyric guy. 

He has a strong dislike for slant rhymes. (I disagreed and it turned into a whole family convo about phonetic tension and release)

He’s still writing every single day without fail. Today he’s writing on an upcoming Pat Metheny record. 

He’s never heard of Drake or Olivia Rodrigo. Mind you his wife was the president of ASCAP for 15 years so this is particularly mind blowing. It shows me how siloed different worlds can be even when they are so similar and near to one another. What wisdom does one silo have on lock that the other is missing? What rules have been taught to us by people in one silo that don’t apply in the silos we ourselves are working in? A lot to chew on here.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Yes, all the time. But my perspective is sort of tough love: nothing you or I do matters. Even if I make a culturally transcendent song, in 100 years we'll all likely be forgotten.

Ok, so then what? Well, you still have a subjective experience of the world. So what is meaning for you? 

Do you like making things? Do you enjoy the process? Do you feel fulfilled and connected to the experience of life by playing piano or singing or mixing or making weird keyboard sounds? 

I love all that shit so much. When I get stressed out and uninspired, I try to find the ways to get me back into making things. When I do, I always feel better. Piano scales or learning songs or playing guitar for my girlfriend or whatever it is that makes me feel joy.

It's very important for me to have significant parts of my life that are creative and not for any purpose.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Ok this is one of my favorite topics ever.

Happy to go deeper, but the gist is this: I believe people connect to the underlying emotion, even if their analytical brain isn't reading or understand the lyrics. If the emotion is authentic, the song has a MUCH better chance of connecting. Without that emotion, it is almost impossible. 

The more I write songs, the older I get, the more I work with the greatest songwriters, the more I think that writing an authentic emotion is everything. 

A favorite example (I have 100 more, just ask): 

Party In The USA. Silly pop song? Or deep truth about the power of music being able to transcend loneliness? Go into the lyric and you realize it's Jessie J writing about her first time coming to Los Angeles: 

Stepped off the plane at LAX with a dream and a cardigan... am I gonna fit in... everybody looks so famous... I'm feeling homesick, too much pressure and I'm nervous... but then my favorite song comes on the radio... I know I'm gonna be ok... it's a party in the USA"

Tbh I tear up every time I think about this song. Yeah people might not analyze the lyric, but the reason this song will play for the next 50 years (and not the 1mil other simple songs about having a party) is the deep, authentic, universal emotion underlying the record.

author: Slow Hand
content:
In this case spaced repetition is your friend. Choose an interval of time that you want to spend practicing a song (10 min, 15 min, 20 min) and practice Song #1 for that amount of time. Then - even if you're not proficient or haven't yet committed the song to memory - move on to practicing Song #2 and let the first song process and consolidate in your memory while you work on Song #2. 

Wash, rinse, repeat until you go through the entire rotation of songs.  If some songs are significantly more difficult to learn or memorize then come back to them more often. The point is to constantly be checking back in on the songs that you're trying to learn just as you're on the threshold of forgetting them.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I used to do a thing like that with a bunch of buddies in LA every September. 

It started cause I wanted to practice using key changes or modal shifts as a songwriting technique, and so I had rules for myself:

1) first idea that fits, wins. No agonizing over lyrics or Melodies or whatever, if it rhymes and makes some kind of sense, move on with it. 
2) first year: ever song needed a key change or modal shift. Second year: shifting or alt time signatures. Third year: some other esoteric tool I wanted to learn etc…
3) the moment you’re done, record a voice memo and send it to someone. Mistakes and all. 

The key for these rules was the make the quality of the songs less important than the act of writing. But damn if I didn’t get two or three real winners every year.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
The other overall point to make is that I find nearly all the great songwriters I know are just comfortable in a session. "Good vibes" in a sense, but also just comfortable generating ideas. They don't really get stuck anywhere. If something isn't working (even if they suggested it), they're comfortable moving forward. Just forward momentum, very little negative energy.

And so much of that is *simply doing it a lot*. It's great to talk about tips and tricks (and yes, morning routines), but mostly it's just putting in time where you're enjoying doing it. 

That's why I think learning songs is so important. It's actually not really about intellectualizing or analyzing what great songs are doing. It's much more just practicing being in the feeling of singing and playing great music. It's the same feeling you're after when you write. By learning great songs and singing them, you get comfortable in that feeling and you're better able to connect to it when writing.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Outside of just getting daily reps, the main goal of this particular practice (the 30 minute write) is that you're setting parameters where you don't have time to decide if something is good. The point is to relieve yourself of any editing and force yourself to quickly write lyrics and melodies. 

It's doing two separate and important things: building muscle memory and teaching to work on instinct.

Building songwriting muscle memory is just like learning a language. You're practicing over and over until you learn how to express yourself emotionally. This is the basics component. You'll learn what notes you can hit and what words rhyme and how rhythms bounce. You'll build a foundation that will become second nature.

Related but distinct, you will learn how to move quickly. It turns out most great songs come in an unthinking way. Until you learn how to write without editing and thinking about what you're doing, you are less likely to write those great songs.

I'm speaking from a lot of personal experience, but also whether it's Hemmingway's "write drunk edit sober," or the Rick Rubin, Pharrell, etc. belief that great songs come from some power outside of ourselves ("Source" or God or whatever), learning to create without being analytical is super super important.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
You're way overthinking it and trying to find some "solutions."

The only thing that important is writing A LOT of songs. The only thing. Only. Yes. Only.

Why? Because forced reps is the only way to learn the language of songwriting. You need to practice over and over to get the muscle memory of writing. It's like the language of an instrument or a literal spoken language.

Any books, tips, videos, classes, spiritual paths, etc etc are only useful right now if they get you to write MORE. But really, you do not need them. I strongly disagree with anyone who says otherwise.

FWIW, my 25 years, billions of streams, platinum hit songs, blah blah has taught me that reps are the ONLY foundation. The best songwriters write all the time and didn't really get good until they'd written hundreds to thousands of songs.

@Zack Hames is on the right track. But don't "attempt" to write a song a day. Force yourself to do it. Immerse like you would learning a language. Don't wait to express yourself perfectly, start writing songs like a five-year-old and work your way up. 

Unlike mixing where you need to learn how things like compression work, or like playing guitar where it's important to have someone show you proper technique, you cannot learn how to be a great songwriter by anything other than doing it over and over*.

author: chadwahlbrink

Quote time 

“Instead of saying, “I’m stuck, I can’t come up with anything good,” it’s far more effective to say, “I’ve finished this, and now I need to make it better.” Or possibly, “I finished this, and it can’t be made better, but now I’m ready to do the new thing, because look at all I’ve learned.” 

This is the story of every human innovation. 
This is the story of every good idea, every new project, every pop song, every novel. There was a bad idea. And then there was a better one. 

If you want to complain that you don’t have any good ideas, please show me all your bad ideas first. 

Befriending your bad ideas is a useful way forward. They’re not your enemy. They are essential steps on the path to better.”

Chap 167 of “The Practice” by Seth Godin.

Sub in “Show me all your bad hooks” or “show me all your bad mixes” and you are headed in the right direction.

author: Brian Reynolds
content:
"The truth is you could slit my throat
And with my one last gasping breath
I'd apologize for bleeding on your shirt"
Taking Back Sunday

I still remember walking into Hot Topic and doing what I always did. Walked directly to the headphones, that had 6 CDs loaded up to choose from listening. Drawn immediately to the NJ Parkway signage and a sticker that said, "If you like Thursday and New Found Glory". Hit play and I was all in from second one. 

The lyrics and especially the one above I couldn't get enough of on this record. They are so visceral and clever. 

The imagery of having you neck slit is like horror and action movie territory. But here it is in an angsty punk rock song about lost love. 

Starting the line with "the truth is" somehow enhances the line slit my throat. Its great storytelling.

Then to top all the clever with the killer line of all killer lines. "I'd apologize for bleeding on your shirt." The painful self awareness that somehow thru it all, your devotion remains. Youre still deferential to your tormentor.

> “Writers these days are more interested in immediate appeal than they are in a great song. They aren’t the same thing. A great song is only a great song if people will want to cover it in 30 years” 

I think about this a lot. My natural tendency (for better or worse) is to sit on records/songs that I've made for myself. No rush. I'll often ask myself "Am I missing the window of opportunity here by not releasing?" and my answer is often some version of "If it's a good record today then, it'll still be a good record tomorrow". Ideally it's release is not dependent on catching a wave before the popularity runs out.

Of course, I'm unlikely to seize upon the cultural zeitgeist with this behavior, and there's a lot of reasons to not do what I do, but Alan's line of thinking feels right for my needs.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Yes x1000

Study the best things, even if they don't always seem to apply directly to what you're doing. 

Max Martin is maybe the best at making vocals sound A+. He is well known as a detail oriented, vocal-focused pop savant. He is often a part of every choice from writing lyrics and melody all the way to adjusting sibilance in the mix. His instincts for great melody and rhythm, paired with lyrics that sound good, is unmatched. And I say "sound good," because though I think many of the lyrics of his songs are meaningful (especially with the best lyric co-writers), the choice of words and how they are emphasized and enunciated is what separates him from everyone else. It's like Michael Jackson. 

Do some YouTube searching on artists talking about working with Max Martin. You can learn a LOT about writing vocal from him.

author: Zack Hames
content:
1. Write a song every day (or attempt) certainly you’ve heard of and likely tried this, but nothing beats reps.

2. More technically, write out the structure (intro, verse, chorus, etc) of some of your favorite songs and mimic it exactly. Even as far as how many measures, or even dynamics (or tempo changes!)

3. If you play an instrument, Learn “great” songs. And ideally sing with them. Playing the best songs in the world will seep into your writing and show you new ideas on chord movements, melodies, and the physicality of a great song.

author: Slow Hand
content:
First off, I’ll second @oaklandmatt’s recommendation that she start exposing herself to a lot of different songs, learning them, and working her writing muscles. A lot of this melodic intuition will come with time, familiarity and having a feel for what’s possible.

How is her ear? I’ve worked with plenty of great singers with little-to-no comprehension for theory. While it can help, I find that for some personality types being too technical and trying to get them to learn theory is a turnoff and is never going to happen. Where does she fit on this spectrum?

Do your best to assure her that she can open up and not be perfect right away. It sounds like she might be clamming up a little bit because she feels uncertain or unconfident. I always try to give my singers a place where they will feel comfortable throwing out any idea. Even horrible ones. It’s okay to fail or fall on your face.  Maybe she needs some reassurance in order to open up. Let her know that she doesn’t have to be perfect. Many singers do better when they have a safe space to open up and attempt new things. Even Prince would tell his engineer to leave the room every time when it became time to track his vocals. Hendrix would hide himself behind a wall of gobos where nobody could see him.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Hmm, probably the likes of @BatMeckley and co could speak to this too, but the social skills ain't always the thing.

I've been in rooms with shy/quieter people who are just incredible at what they do. In one case, on a very high profile session, one of the beatmakers literally didn't speak to anyone, ever. He was 19 at the time, literally only opened his mouth to very politely ask me for my email address so he could fly the beat into Pro Tools to cut vocals. But he was making absolute fire, and even though he didn't speak, you could feel a good vibe off him.

I've also been in rooms with *unbelievably* obnoxious characters (the occasional particularly unpleasant example of that LA type we were discussing recently). Utterly repugnant as people, but their work is undeniable.

I know who I prefer to be in a room with (and that really does count for a lot, in my experience), but in the speed dating world of pop music writing that a lot of people go through, you get all sorts. 

Not everyone is super charismatic of course, but that's just the world. Either way, 90% of the people I've met at the highest level are really delightful.

Also, my experience has been that the more accomplished the artist/writer/producer, the more lovely they've been. They've got nothing to prove, and perhaps at a certain level, anyone who's not truly undeniable has already been filtered out of those rooms by being a jerk on the way there.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
All just personal experiences and my interpretation thereof, but I do feel like there's some universals in there.

Have you tried co-writing generally? I started by rustling up sessions on Instagram. Low stakes, artists I thought were cool but just getting started etc. Low stakes rooms to start with, and it was just as well because I made some really crucial errors in those sessions that really sunk the vibe. I'm glad they happened in those settings so I could learn the lessons there, and not a little further on.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
We’ve all got those cringe moments! They suck, but they also don’t define you. We all live and learn.

I’d absolutely recommend getting in rooms with anyone you can. The more serious they are, the better, but there is value in just getting the reps in. Probably would’ve been an easier pill to swallow to have that experience where you choked on the beat in a lower pressure session, right?

And there’s always zoom. If you’ve got some work you’re proud of online, you can reach out to artists you like to set up a remote session. Never quite the same as being in the room, but plenty to learn there too. And your network expands - that part is huge.

Hey Matt! Had a question…regarding all this songwriting. I don’t do it anymore, I just master but I am playing with a lot of these ideas applied to my own workflow…i.e. finishing things, focusing on my intuitive flow state…letting things just “come” to me.

Just curious if this kind of stuff is on your mind and something you’re actively pursuing.

author: Deleted User
content:
I think that is what I am after; How do you say the same idea or concept/story but deliver it tastefully. Just like the same E major chord could be delivered in different voicings and different style of playing or instruments even. 

Maybe it’s just about paying attention to it more. I generally pay more attention to music than words by default, so that might be a factor that plays into it. 

Technically- with drums for example, you can use the same tools, try to play it or sequence it with the feel as close to it as possible, and break down what’s on it in terms of processing. If I go further, I can look at how the drums are interacting with the rest of the ensemble. If I just want to rip off the drums from a song, the first three will pretty much get me there. 

D’Angelo’s Voodoo is an album I constantly go back to study for the band interaction. Questlove is usually playing straight eighth notes, and very simple pattern. but how open the hihat is, and where he’s hitting, and when he makes the choices to pop the hihat out or kind of let it hide behind the instrumentation is very interesting. Perhaps subtle spontaneous decisions like that isn’t really replicable but I just take it in physically and try to see why he made this by looking at what other instruments are doing. You can just pay attention to how he plays hi hat and go wild playing just the hat along

author: Deleted User
content:
I’ve tried different ways with hangs- I’m still figuring out. And I typically don’t touch lyrics anymore because I’ve found that I’m not that great at lyrics yet and if I don’t have a line (which I usually don’t….), it’s better to leave it be for the longevity of relationship because lyrics can be one of the most personal things in music making because… it is literal. If you are more lyrics person, I think you can get a lot of value out of hanging out. 

First thing is creating safe space- and it really depends on person to person. Some people never open up, some people can open up immediately. In my experience, the more experienced they are - the more they tend to be the latter. I think how much time you spend on it can be dependent on this. You mentioned wanting to be more intentional, one idea that came to my mind is communicating this from the get go. Obviously there are going to be times where bring this up can be weird in the beginning of the session, but it should get them to think about opening up as part of work at the very least. It needs to be done carefully of course

The other part of it is understanding the person themselves. Their general vibe and energy. It’s easier to tell with some folks, and it’s harder to know what kind of person it is with some other folks. regarding this, I find diving into work right away helps feel it out. my job is often to constantly create ideas and inspirations. I can often gather some information from how they respond to different ideas. 

Lastly, I used to spend a lot of time hanging up until very recently and I found it’s so much more productive to just work and bond through that experience. Nature of work calls for connecting on a personal level, but it doesn’t require it. I’ve been trying to take it easy on getting closer with people, and focusing on the overall experience of collaboration and it has been making sessions more productive. So I plan on sticking with this way for a bit and see how it goes!

author: Pio
content:
Late to this one, hope your songwriting journey is going great this past while! 

If you’re still looking for more on this, and don’t mind a little reading, I was recommended Pat Pattinson’s Write Better Lyrics years ago and I found it a super helpful tool - I loved the recommendation of a 10 min a day exercise of ‘object writing’, and also the idea of thinking about your verses as a way of ‘loading’ story and fuel for your choruses. 

Jeff Tweedy also has an even shorter but really uplifting book on writing called ‘How to Write One Song’, which is excellent. It’s more geared towards the personal, less towards industry, but I’m so convicted that writing personal songs IS the way to reach others that I would definitely recommend it too.

author: Pio
content:
And if you don’t wanna go buying books, I’d recommend possibly trying out the daily practice of object writing; you could even try it for a week or so, and you’ll end up getting interesting imagery, some of which you may be able to use in your songs - but if you stick at it a bit (I find if I do it solidly in the mornings for a week or two it just warms my brain right up for writing throughout the day) it can help get your brain into that mode, so that when you go into your writing sessions later, your brain is already making those connections. Just an option of course - everyone’s got their own way with lyric, it really is so personal. Whatever tools help, use em, whatever tools don’t, chuck em. 

I just mention these things bc you talk about making the songs ‘real’, and I feel that - I love trying to get a song to feel properly grounded, with a sense of place and reality. Best solution I’ve found is to just leave a bit of me in there - somehow it’s like people can feel when songwriting is ‘real’, so I just try to make sure my heart is in/behind each line, keep them smooth, rinse repeat 

Would love to crack open this topic again too, curious on more peoples thoughts on this stuff, thanks for opening this up  @OJ,

author: revolution
content:
im not a professional, pretty new to music in the sense of trying to create a product/song. Ive been an instrumentalist, engineer, writer, etc etc as a hobby or interest from time to time... and i notice that writing is one of the areas that I have the least doubts about myself. i fully believe i can write interesting bars/emotions/etc from time to time... but it's very much an abstract 'writing' skill that could be applied to poetry or essays or anything... rather than a reflection of my actual song writing ability.

i want to learn how to hone my strengths and bridge the gap between having or putting out decent ideas (wether lyrical or melodic) and actually distilling a song structure and 'product' if you will. A good analogy is the gap between someone with good cinematography instincts/eye vs a director/writer/editor level of structure or authorship

author: revolution
content:
i guess other forms of art like film or books often do require a lot of structure and thought in order to cohesively convey or execute a vision... even if the vision is fundamentally grounded on a seed of feeling or very specific idea. songs and music are so temporal and intuitive that it doesnt really require that necessarily. 

for better and worse, i tend to have this desire to seek out a 'scientific' nature in things. for me as a fan of films, i can often decipher or intuit the internal logic and intentionality that choreographs lights and angles and framing to create a moving feeling/painting. 

i do fully agree that fundamentally the only thing that can create this sense of 'spatial awareness' in a medium, or a sense of dialectic/causality between the subtle and intuitive, creative elements is experience and repetition; but i can't help but seek out knowledge or structure/self critique to my approach.

i think to that end, i should collaborate more with people who are experienced so i can accelerate my own learning if that's what i seek. i find myself always searching for this 'internal' awareness of intentionality, searching for the forces and patterns that make a system or experience exist and change how they do.

i am alwasy looking for this feeling of purpose or understanding of which steps are wanted/needed for me to take what ive created closer to its essence or my original vision. i think people understand this at the level of more technical creative aspects... for example mixing. ultimately the art is still to have a creative vision and executing that, but it's the experience and awareness to have intentionality and wisdom in how to execute that separates raw creativity/talent from a professional level of execution no? I think the same can be applied to more abstract skills like writing/songwriting.

i'm going to commit to writing new material everyday for a month and see what happens!

author: revolution
content:
idk what qualifies as a song or not.. but to this end, by chance before i got time to read everyone's response, i happened to turn a small poem and a few lyrics into a valentine voice note for a friend. by nature of simply singing it and imbuing it with melody it sort of became a song. in some sense, its that easy, and i am failing myself by not carving out the time and commitment to that every single day.

perhaps what im asking is really a reflection of a lack of courage and patience/grit. where i'd like technical and direct feedback, i search for 'knowledge' and 'technique' instead of collaborators and mentors. where i am afraid to fail, i avoid the daunting task of putting ink on a blank canvas every day. 

i honestly fully agree and expected your answer to be the primary one!
